Title.evidence: Laser Epilation in Pilonidal Disease: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants aged 11 to 21 years with pilonidal disease were randomised

Participants.evidence: Participants aged 11 to 21 years with pilonidal disease were randomised to receive either laser epilation (LE) with standard care or standard care alone.

Intervention.evidence: Participants aged 11 to 21 years with pilonidal disease were randomised to receive either laser epilation (LE) with standard care or standard care alone.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the recurrence rate of pilonidal disease at 1 year.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 302 participants were randomised: 151 to the LE group and 151 to the standard care group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: One-year follow-up data were available for 96 patients in the LE group and 134 in the standard care group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The recurrence rate was significantly lower in the LE group (−23.2%; 95% CI, −33.2 to −13.1; P < .001).
